topics.title: AWS Core Services

keyFormulas.formula:

RDS: Managed SQL databases
DynamoDB: NoSQL, millisecond latency

definition.text: Cloud security encompasses policies, controls, and technologies that protect cloud-based systems and data. Understanding the shared responsibility model is crucial.

keyFormulas.name: Shared Responsibility Model
keyFormulas.formula:
Provider: Physical infra, network, hypervisor
Customer: Data, access (IAM), app security, OS patches
keyFormulas.meaning: Security is a shared duty between provider and customer

keyFormulas.name: IAM Concepts
keyFormulas.formula:
Users â†’ Groups â†’ Roles â†’ Policies
Principle: Least Privilege Always
keyFormulas.meaning: Control who can access what in your cloud

topics.title: Multi-Cloud Architecture

definition.text: Multi-cloud strategy involves using multiple cloud providers to host applications and services. It provides redundancy, avoids vendor lock-in, and leverages best-of-breed services from different providers.

keyFormulas.name: Multi-Cloud Trade-offs
keyFormulas.formula:
Pros: Avoid lock-in, redundancy, best services
Cons: Complexity, expertise needed, data transfer costs
keyFormulas.meaning: Multi-cloud adds flexibility but increases complexity

examples.question: Design a multi-cloud application
examples.finalAnswer: Portable application deployable to any cloud

realWorldApplications.title: Best of Breed
realWorldApplications.description: ML on GCP, compute on AWS

tips: Start with one cloud, add others strategically
Abstract at the right level - not everything needs portability
Consider data transfer costs between clouds

topics.title: Cloud-Native Architecture

definition.text: Cloud-native architecture is an approach to building applications that fully exploit cloud computing advantages. It embraces microservices, containers, declarative APIs, and immutable infrastructure to achieve scalability, resilience, and rapid iteration.

keyFormulas.name: 12-Factor App Principles
keyFormulas.formula:
1. Codebase (one repo, many deploys)
2. Dependencies (explicitly declare)
3. Config (store in environment)
4. Backing Services (treat as resources)
5. Build/Release/Run (strict separation)
6. Processes (stateless, share nothing)

steps.explanation: Git as single source of truth

codeExample.yaml:
# GitOps: ArgoCD Application
apiVersion: argoproj.io/v1alpha1
kind: Application
metadata:
  name: my-app
  namespace: argocd
spec:
  project: default
  source:
    repoURL: https://github.com/org/manifests
    targetRevision: HEAD
    path: apps/my-app
  destination:
    server: https://kubernetes.default.svc
    namespace: production
  syncPolicy:
    automated:
      prune: true
      selfHeal: true

tips: Don't rewrite everything at once - strangle the monolith
Invest heavily in observability from day one
Team organization should mirror architecture (Conway's Law)
Use feature flags for safe releases

topics.title: FinOps & Cloud Cost Optimization

definition.text: FinOps (Cloud Financial Operations) is the practice of bringing financial accountability to cloud spending. It combines systems, best practices, and culture to optimize cloud costs while maintaining performance and reliability.

keyFormulas.name: Cost Optimization Levers
keyFormulas.formula:
Right-sizing: Match instance to workload
Reserved/Savings Plans: Commit for discounts
Spot Instances: Use spare capacity
Auto-scaling: Scale down when idle
Storage Tiering: Move cold data cheaper
keyFormulas.meaning: Multiple strategies to reduce cloud costs

keyFormulas.name: Unit Economics
keyFormulas.formula:
Cost per Request = Total Cloud Cost / Total Requests
Cost per User = Total Cloud Cost / Active Users
Track these metrics over time for efficiency gains

codeExample.python:
# AWS Cost Analysis Script
import boto3
from datetime import datetime, timedelta

def get_cost_by_service(days=30):
    client = boto3.client('ce')  # Cost Explorer
    
    end = datetime.now()
    start = end - timedelta(days=days)
    
    response = client.get_cost_and_usage(
        TimePeriod={
            'Start': start.strftime('%Y-%m-%d'),
            'End': end.strftime('%Y-%m-%d')
        },
        Granularity='MONTHLY',
        Metrics=['UnblendedCost'],
        GroupBy=[{'Type': 'DIMENSION', 'Key': 'SERVICE'}]
    )
    
    for result in response['ResultsByTime']:
        print(f"Period: {result['TimePeriod']['Start']}")
        for group in sorted(result['Groups'], 
                           key=lambda x: float(x['Metrics']['UnblendedCost']['Amount']),
                           reverse=True)[:10]:
            service = group['Keys'][0]
            cost = float(group['Metrics']['UnblendedCost']['Amount'])
            print(f"  {service}: ${cost:.2f}")

tips: Tag everything for cost allocation
Set up billing alerts and budgets
Review costs weekly, not monthly
Make cost a first-class engineering concern
Automate instance scheduling for dev environments

topics.title: Edge Computing & CDN

definition.text: Edge computing brings computation and data storage closer to users, reducing latency and bandwidth usage. Combined with CDNs, it enables sub-millisecond response times and processes data at the edge of the network.

keyFormulas.name: Edge Computing Benefits
keyFormulas.formula:
Lower Latency: Process near user
Reduced Bandwidth: Filter/aggregate at edge
Resilience: Distribute across locations
Regional Compliance: Data stays in region
keyFormulas.meaning: Bring compute to where data is generated/consumed

keyFormulas.name: CDN Caching Strategy
keyFormulas.formula:
Cache-Control headers â†’ CDN caches at edge â†’ TTL expires â†’ Revalidate
Hit ratio = Cached requests / Total requests (target > 90%)
keyFormulas.meaning: Effective caching dramatically reduces origin load

tips: Cache static content aggressively (long TTL)
